results.title: Bottle rocket
results.creator_credit: Wes Anderson, Cynthia Hargrave, Polly Platt, Gracie Films and Colombia Pictures
results.brief_description: Wes Anderson’s first feature film is a whimsical tale of three suburban misfits who attempt to commit the perfect robbery but end up in trouble with the local “Godfather” (played by James Caan). The conventions of the crime film are used as launch-pads for Anderson to construct a low-key but nevertheless deeply affecting romance about small-time lives and experience. The script, co-written by Anderson and star Owen Wilson, takes three friends on a mid-Western road trip in which Anthony (Luke Wilson) finds love with a Mexican immigrant, Inez (Lumi Cavazos); Dignan (Owen Wilson) plays out all his fantasies of being a master criminal; and Bob Mapplethorpe (Robert Musgrave) finds out that blood is, indeed, thicker than water. By finding beauty and comedy in the deeply suburban locales, Anderson is able to satirize the insularity of bourgeois American families and values without being condescending or cynical. The idiosyncratic, colourful and playful mise-en-scene of “Rushmore” and “The Royal Tenenbaums” is clearly evident in Anderson’s debut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wes Anderson, Cynthia Hargrave, Polly Platt, Gracie Films and Colombia Pictures

results.title: Botticelli: visions of beauty and violence
results.brief_description: Sandro Botticelli was one of the most popular and sought after artists of the Renaissance, renowned for his religious and mythological subjects and the beauty and sensuality of his painting. Working almost exclusively out of Florence, except for a stint in Rome to paint frescos for the Sistine Chapel, the bulk of his output was commissioned work for wealthy patrons such as the powerful Medici family. His friend and benefactor, Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de’ Medici, commissioned Botticelli to provide illustrations for a copy of what has been viewed as the greatest ever work of Italian literature - Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy. Given complete artistic control over the project, Botticelli worked on the drawings between 1480 and 1495, and although they remain unfinished, they are viewed as some of the most enduring examples of his stylistic virtuosity. Working closely with Dante’s text, he painstakingly created illustrations for each section of the poem on fine goatskin parchment, expertly creating a visual interpretation of the poet’s epic passage through Hell, Purgatory and Paradise. A selection of art experts discuss the spiritual and political content, historical background and artistic execution of this work, and speculate on what drove this “explorer of beauty” to produce such a unique and animated accompaniment to Dante’s written account of the journey of the soul.

results.title: Bossa pop
results.creator_credit: Sheldon Cohen, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Three animated figures, a man, a woman and a child, dance, arms and legs flying, to the compulsive rhythms of this Bossa Pop. A light film in carnival mood - who can remain still when the music commands? A film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sheldon Cohen, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Border country
results.creator_credit: Peter Thompson, Jill Robb, South Australian Film Corporation and Trojan Films
results.brief_description: A cinematic exploration of South Eastern South Australia, a region that combines the wild beauty of The Coorong with lush grazing properties, pine forests, Mt Gambier’s famous Blue Lake, and the quiet charm of small fishing villages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Thompson, Jill Robb, South Australian Film Corporation and Trojan Films

results.title: Bootmen [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dein Perry, Hilary Linstead and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Loosely based on director Dein Perry’s early life as a dancer, “Bootmen” is the story of two brothers - Sean (Adam Garcia) and Mitchell (Sam Worthington) - working in a steel mill in the industrial city of Newcastle. Both dream of one day escaping from the mill, Sean as a tap dancer in Sydney and Mitchell purchasing a tow truck to get out of the only life their stern father has ever known. Tension arrises between the brothers when Sean quits the mill to go to Sydney to study with a well known dance troupe and Mitchell moves in on Sean’s woman, Linda (Sophie Lee), both brothers finding themselves in love with her. “Bootmen” is a feel-good movie that is similar in genre to “Strictly Ballroom” and “The Full Monty”, a touching and sweet film with wonderful tap dancing sequences. Cast also includes William Zappa, Richard Carter and Susie Porter.

holdings.name: ISO; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: Boomsville
results.creator_credit: Yvon Mallette, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An amusing diagnosis of big city growing pains. This film is an ironic view of town planning or rather, the lack of it and what has happened to our cities as a result. Done in cartoon animation, the film traces the growth of the typical city, from a tiny settlement in the vast North American wilderness to the car-clogged metropolis that so many cities are today. Awards: New York; Oberhousen; Les Menuires.

results.title: Boomer
results.creator_credit: Dale Phillips, Michael Scott, Tom Radford and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: For some of us home and work are not in the same place. Well paid as a boiler-maker, Gary Honig must often leave home to exercise his highly specialised skill. Sometimes, his wife and two daughters accompany him in their trailer but more often they remain behind in their home in Stony Creek, Alberta. The film describes how one family copes, combining family life, and work in the increasingly industrialised West.

results.title: Boolean procedure
results.creator_credit: Nicola Bruce, Michael Coulson and Muscle Films
results.brief_description: The introduction of Micro-technology has brought about change and crisis, which will alter our value systems and the way we spend our time. Through a bizarre mutation of live action and exciting graphic animation, the film makes us passengers in a world of artificial voices, plastic sound and faceless people. This film was shown at the Melbourne Film Festival, 1981.

results.title: Born to be wild
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Jeffrey Silver, Robert Newmyer, Outlaw Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Katie is a very special three year old gorilla who knows how to communicate using sign language and loves to talk to her friend, Rick (Will Horneff). Rick meets Katie through his mother, a behavioural scientist who is so busy working with animals that she doesn’t have time for her son who is sinking into juvenile delinquency. Their friendship is threatened when Katie is reclaimed by her former owner and put in a cage with the intention of being used as an attraction at the flea market. Rick helps Katie escape and together they embark on an exciting wilderness adventure from California to Canada and having a lot of fun along the way. Cast includes Wil Horneff, Helen Shaver, John C McGinley and Peter Boyle.

results.title: Books for Beaver River
results.creator_credit: Donald Ginsberg, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: It took a boy with his eyes on the stars to show that even the best town is a poor town when it has no place for books. Beaver River, a farming community in north central Saskatchewan, has paved roads, a new school, a curling rink, and many television sets, but no place where a boy could find a book about the stars. In this film Beaver River gets its own library and, in the process, illustrates Saskatchewan’s regional library system which provides book loans at minimum costs to municipality and province. This film is historically good for the pictorial/architecture/general life style of such a country town of it’s time.
